commander.name: Lieutenant-General Noel Beresford-Peirse
commander.previous_service: Commander, 4th Indian Division during Operation Compass; East Africa campaign

Matilda II.note: Infantry tanks with 4th Armoured Brigade (4th RTR, 7th RTR) for Operation Battleaxe

fighters.note: Air support provided by RAF Western Desert Air Force (independent command)

supply_logistics.supply_status: Strained for offensive operations. Operation Battleaxe suffered from inadequate fuel and ammunition reserves. Primary constraint: 600km supply line from railhead at Mersa Matruh to forward positions at Sollum-Halfaya. Poor port facilities at Tobruk (under siege) forced reliance on overland transport.

weather_environment.terrain_type: coastal plain (Sollum-Bardia) and rocky desert plateau (escarpment)

subordinate_units.note: Primary armoured striking force with 4th and 7th Armoured Brigades
Recalled from East Africa for Operation Battleaxe. Included 11th Indian Infantry Brigade and other attached units
Attached to XIII Corps for Operation Battleaxe. Motorised infantry support
Artillery regiments, engineers, signals, medical, supply, maintenance

tactical_doctrine.role: Operational-level formation responsible for coordinating combined-arms offensive to relieve Tobruk and recapture Cyrenaica from Axis forces. Executed Operation Battleaxe (15-17 June 1941).
special_capabilities: Mobile operations in open desert terrain
tactical_innovations: First large-scale use of Crusader cruiser tanks in North Africa
Attempted coordination between slow Matilda infantry tanks (8 mph) and faster Crusader cruisers (27 mph)
known_issues: Tank speed disparity: Matilda II infantry tanks too slow (8 mph max) for desert mobile warfare
2-pounder anti-tank guns inadequate penetration vs German 50mm frontal armor
British tanks vulnerable to German 88mm AA guns in anti-tank role
Slow command reaction time vs German tactical flexibility
Inadequate radio communication between armoured brigades
Fuel and ammunition logistics strained by 600km supply line
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Water rationing (4L/day/person), vehicle maintenance against sand infiltration, navigation by sun compass and dead reckoning

special_rules: Tank speed disparity: Matilda II moves at 1/3 speed of Crusader cruisers
German 88mm AA guns in anti-tank role ignore British tank armor
British command penalty: -1 initiative vs German tactical flexibility
Supply constraints: Fuel limited to 4.5 days offensive operations
historical_engagements: Operation Battleaxe (15-17 June 1941) - Failed to relieve Tobruk, heavy tank losses (91 tanks destroyed/damaged)
Halfaya Pass defense breakthrough attempt (repulsed by German 88mm guns)

source: The Rommel Papers (Liddell Hart, 1953) - British offensive June 1941 section
Military Wiki - Operation Battleaxe order of battle
World War II Database - Operation Battleaxe

chief_of_staff.name.reason: Chief of Staff name not mentioned in primary sources (Rommel Papers, British Army Lists). Corps-level staff records require archival research.
chief_of_staff.name.mitigation: Archival research at Imperial War Museum or National Archives (Kew) required

exact_subordinate_unit_strengths.reason: Precise personnel counts for subordinate divisions not available in accessible sources. Estimates based on British divisional TO&E standards 1941.
sources_checked: The Rommel Papers (mentions 7 British divisions total in theater, not individual strengths)
Operation Battleaxe order of battle sources
TM 30-410 (provides typical division strengths, not specific June 1941 actuals)
exact_subordinate_unit_strengths.estimate_method: Standard British armoured division: 18,000 personnel; Infantry division: 17,000; Independent brigade: 3,200. Applied to known units.

exact_vehicle_counts.reason: Tank counts (170-250 range) documented for Operation Battleaxe total force. Specific variant breakdown and soft-skin vehicle counts estimated from British armoured/infantry division TO&E standards.
exact_vehicle_counts.estimate_method: Tank distribution: 90 Matilda II (4th Armoured Brigade documented), 120 cruisers (Crusader + A13 mix), 30 light tanks. Soft-skin vehicles estimated at corps level using British 1941 scales.
